div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, February 22, 1924
div1.opener:
I. H. B
Brazil
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
February 22/24.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I am much obliged for the carbon of Noguchi's letter enclosed
in yours of February 20th.

His visit to Brazil has unquestionably been a success, both from
a scientific and administrative standpoint.

I am inclined to think that wherever you find the German in-
fluence strong in South America (scientific or otherwise) you will
find a tendency to hold work by any other people as worthy of lit-
tle respect, and I had an idea this would be especially so in, at
least the northern part of Brazil where, in 1916, da Rocha Lima
was quoted to me continuously as if there had never been any other
pathologist investibating yellow fever. He (a native of Ceara) is
I judge more German than Brazilian. Noguchi showed consumate tact--
and tact founded on good feeling--when he had the Brazilians find
their own Leptospirae. His prestige will help us in Brazil from a
scientific standpoint and his popularity from an administrative one.

I am hoping that, although an enormous country, the work in
Brazil will not be very extensive. One would think that such a
large proportion of the people in the towns in which yellow fever
fever
2
exists are immunized that the disease would not require a very
great rediction of the aegypti index for its disappearance.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours,
P. S. It is absolutely certain--from epidemiological data--that there
was no (or very little) infestation of the country around Monte Video
and in Rio Grand del Sul with yellow fever when the disease first
visited the former city.
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
